title: Haggai Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Haggai chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Haggai Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Haggai Chapter 2.

questions.question: On what day of the seventh month did the word of the LORD come by the prophet Haggai?
questions.correctAnswer: 21st day
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:1 states the word of the LORD came in the seventh month, on the twenty-first day of the month.

questions.question: Who was spoken to by the LORD through the prophet Haggai alongside Zerubbabel and the residue of the people?
questions.correctAnswer: Joshua the son of Josedech
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:2 mentions Joshua the son of Josedech, the high priest, as one of those addressed by the LORD.

questions.question: According to Haggai 2:3, how did the people see the house now compared to its first glory?
questions.correctAnswer: As nothing in comparison
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states the house was seen as nothing compared to its first glory.

questions.question: What three groups does the LORD command to 'be strong' and work in Haggai 2:4?
options: Zerubbabel, Joshua, and all the people
questions.correctAnswer: Zerubbabel, Joshua, and all the people
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:4 calls Zerubbabel, Joshua son of Josedech, and all the people to be strong and work.

questions.question: According to Haggai 2:5, what remains among the people as the LORD covenanted when they came out of Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: His spirit
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states the LORD's spirit remains among the people as He covenanted.

questions.question: What will the LORD shake according to Haggai 2:6?
options: Heavens, earth, sea, and dry land
questions.correctAnswer: Heavens, earth, sea, and dry land
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:6 says the LORD will shake the heavens, earth, sea, and dry land.

questions.question: According to Haggai 2:7, what shall come and fill the house with glory?
questions.correctAnswer: The desire of all nations
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states the desire of all nations shall come and the house will be filled with glory.

questions.question: Who declares 'The silver is mine, and the gold is mine' in Haggai 2:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:8 states that the LORD of hosts claims the silver and gold as His.

questions.question: What will be greater in glory according to Haggai 2:9?
questions.correctAnswer: The latter house
questions.explanation: Verse 9 says the glory of the latter house will be greater than the former.

questions.question: When did the word of the LORD come again to Haggai according to Haggai 2:10?
options: 24th day of the ninth month, second year of Darius
questions.correctAnswer: 24th day of the ninth month, second year of Darius
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:10 states the LORD's word came on the 24th day of the ninth month in the second year of Darius.

questions.question: True or False: According to Haggai 2:12, if one bears holy flesh in the skirt of his garment and touches bread, the bread becomes holy.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:12 states the priests answered 'No' to whether touching bread with holy flesh makes it holy.

questions.question: True or False: Haggai 2:13 states that if an unclean person touches food, the food becomes unclean.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:13 says the priests answered that if one unclean by a dead body touches these things, they become unclean.

questions.question: True or False: Haggai 2:17 indicates that despite being smitten with blasting, mildew, and hail, the people turned to God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:17 says the people were smitten yet did not turn to God.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Haggai 2:23: 'In that day, saith the LORD of hosts, will I take thee, O Zerubbabel, my servant, the son of ________, saith the LORD, and will make thee as a signet.'
questions.correctAnswer: Shealtiel
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:23 identifies Zerubbabel as the son of Shealtiel.

questions.question: According to Haggai 2:19, from the day the foundation of the LORD's temple was laid, what will the LORD do?
questions.correctAnswer: Bless you
questions.explanation: Verse 19 promises blessing from the day the temple foundation was laid.

medium.title: Haggai Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Haggai Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged about the small progress in their spiritual growth. Based on Haggai 2, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance and God's presence?
options: Be strong and work, for God is with you
Give up until you feel stronger
Wait for God to act without effort
questions.correctAnswer: Be strong and work, for God is with you
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:4 encourages Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the people to be strong and work because God is with them. This teaches us to persevere in faith and work diligently, trusting God's presence.

questions.question: How does Haggai 2 teach about trusting God's promises during difficult times?
options: Fear not, for the Spirit remains among you
Rely only on your own strength
Ignore God's promises until they happen
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not, for the Spirit remains among you
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:5 reminds the people not to fear because God's Spirit remains with them as per His covenant, encouraging trust in God's faithfulness during hardships.

questions.question: What does Haggai 2 teach about humility and contentment when comparing present circumstances with past glories?
options: Recognize the present as small but trust God for greater glory
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize the present as small but trust God for greater glory
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:3 and 2:9 show that though the current temple seems insignificant compared to the former, God promises the latter glory will be greater, teaching humility and hopeful contentment.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear about the future. Based on Haggai 2, what encouragement can you give about God's control over nations and circumstances?
options: God will shake the heavens and earth and overthrow kingdoms
questions.correctAnswer: God will shake the heavens and earth and overthrow kingdoms
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:6, 2:7, and 2:22 declare God's sovereign power to shake the heavens, earth, and nations, assuring believers that God controls all circumstances and is working His purposes.

questions.question: How does Haggai 2 emphasize the importance of holiness in what believers offer to God?
options: Uncleanness in the people causes offerings to be unclean
Holiness is not important in offerings
Offerings must be large to be accepted
questions.correctAnswer: Uncleanness in the people causes offerings to be unclean
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:14 explains that the people's uncleanness made their offerings unclean, teaching the practical need for holiness and purity in worship and daily life.

questions.question: What lesson about integrity in work and stewardship can be drawn from Haggai 2:16-17?
options: God's discipline came because the people did not turn to Him
Hard work guarantees success without God's blessing
questions.correctAnswer: God's discipline came because the people did not turn to Him
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:16-17 shows that despite their efforts, the people's labors failed because they did not turn to God, highlighting the need for integrity and dependence on God in stewardship.

questions.question: A believer questions whether blessings will come after hard work. What does Haggai 2:18-19 teach about God's timing and blessing?
options: From the day the temple's foundation was laid, God promises to bless
questions.correctAnswer: From the day the temple's foundation was laid, God promises to bless
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:18-19 encourages believers to consider the time from the temple foundation onward, promising God's blessing, teaching patience and trust in God's timing.

questions.question: How does Haggai 2 portray God's ownership and stewardship principles?
options: The silver and gold belong to God
questions.correctAnswer: The silver and gold belong to God
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:8 states that silver and gold belong to God, underscoring the biblical principle that all resources are God's and believers are stewards of His blessings.

questions.question: What encouragement does Haggai 2:23 give about leadership and God's calling in service?
options: God has chosen Zerubbabel and will make him a signet
Leadership is unimportant in God's plan
questions.correctAnswer: God has chosen Zerubbabel and will make him a signet
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:23 reveals God's choice of Zerubbabel as a signet, symbolizing God's authority and trust in chosen leaders for His purposes, encouraging faithful service.

questions.question: True or False: According to Haggai 2, God promises that the glory of the latter house will be less than the former house.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:9 states that the glory of the latter house will be greater than the former, showing God's promise of future blessing and greater glory.

questions.question: True or False: Haggai 2 teaches that God's Spirit will depart from the people if they fail in their work.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:5 assures that God's Spirit remains among the people according to His covenant, encouraging trust despite challenges.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Haggai 2, God says, 'I will fill this house with ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: glory
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:7 promises that God will fill the house with glory, indicating His presence and blessing in the rebuilt temple.

questions.question: How does Haggai 2 illustrate the importance of spiritual cleanliness in daily life?
options: Touching something holy does not make common food holy
Anything touched by the holy is automatically holy
Only priests need to be holy
questions.correctAnswer: Touching something holy does not make common food holy
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:12 explains that holy flesh touching common food does not make it holy, teaching that holiness must be intentional and not accidental or superficial.

questions.question: What lesson about repentance and turning back to God does Haggai 2 provide when facing trials?
options: God's discipline is to call for repentance, not punishment without hope
questions.correctAnswer: God's discipline is to call for repentance, not punishment without hope
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:17 shows that God’s blasting, mildew, and hail were disciplinary to bring the people to repentance, teaching that trials can lead to spiritual renewal.

questions.question: How does Haggai 2 encourage believers to view their work and efforts in God's service?
options: Work with strength and confidence because God is with you
Work only when you feel like it
Ignore God's presence in your work
questions.correctAnswer: Work with strength and confidence because God is with you
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:4 encourages the people to be strong and work confidently, trusting that God is with them, emphasizing diligence and faith.

hard.title: Haggai Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Haggai Chapter 2.

questions.question: To whom does the LORD command Haggai to speak in Haggai 2:2?
options: Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the residue of the people
questions.correctAnswer: Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the residue of the people
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:2 explicitly mentions that the word of the LORD was to be spoken to Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, Joshua the son of Josedech the high priest, and the residue of the people.

questions.question: What encouragement does God give Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the people in Haggai 2:4?
options: Be strong and work, for the LORD is with you
questions.correctAnswer: Be strong and work, for the LORD is with you
questions.explanation: In Haggai 2:4, God commands Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the people to be strong and work because the LORD of hosts is with them, providing divine encouragement and presence.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'shaking' mentioned in Haggai 2:6-7?
options: It symbolizes God's sovereign intervention across heaven, earth, and nations
It refers to an earthquake that destroyed the temple
It is a metaphor for the people's fear of invasion
It denotes the collapse of the Babylonian empire
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's sovereign intervention across heaven, earth, and nations
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:6-7 uses the imagery of shaking the heavens, earth, sea, and dry land as a metaphor for God’s sovereign and universal intervention affecting all creation and nations.

questions.question: According to Haggai 2:8, who owns the silver and gold?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:8 clearly states that the silver and gold belong to the LORD of hosts, emphasizing God's ownership over all wealth and resources.

questions.question: What comparison does God make about the temple in Haggai 2:9?
options: The glory of the latter house will be greater than the former
The latter house will be smaller and less glorious
The temple will be destroyed again
The glory will remain the same as before
questions.correctAnswer: The glory of the latter house will be greater than the former
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:9 promises that the glory of the rebuilt temple will surpass that of the former temple, indicating a hopeful future and divine blessing.

questions.question: What legal question does Haggai ask the priests in Haggai 2:12?
options: If holy flesh touches common food, does it make them holy?
Can a Gentile serve in the temple?
Is it lawful to rebuild the temple now?
Can one eat meat sacrificed to idols?
questions.correctAnswer: If holy flesh touches common food, does it make them holy?
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:12 records a question about purity laws concerning whether holy flesh touching other food makes them holy, which the priests answered negatively.

questions.question: What is the answer given by the priests when asked if unclean flesh can contaminate food in Haggai 2:13?
options: Only if touched by a priest
questions.correctAnswer: Yes, it shall be unclean
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:13 shows the priests affirming that touching unclean flesh does indeed make other items unclean, underscoring the strict purity laws.

questions.question: In Haggai 2:14, what does Haggai say about the people and their offerings?
options: Their works and offerings are unclean before God
Their sacrifices are accepted with joy
They have been faithful and pure
Their offerings are greater than before
questions.correctAnswer: Their works and offerings are unclean before God
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:14 declares that the people, their nation, and every work of their hands, including offerings, are unclean before the LORD, indicating a need for repentance.

questions.question: What does the LORD say will happen from the 24th day of the ninth month onward (Haggai 2:18-19)?
options: He will bless the people, even though crops have not yet grown
The people will suffer famine and drought
The temple will be destroyed again
questions.correctAnswer: He will bless the people, even though crops have not yet grown
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:18-19 indicates that from that day, God will bless the people despite the current barren state of the land, symbolizing future restoration and hope.

questions.question: What is the significance of Zerubbabel being called a 'signet' in Haggai 2:23?
options: It symbolizes God's chosen authority and covenant with him
It indicates he will become king of Israel
It means he is a priest of the temple
It is a title for the high priest
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's chosen authority and covenant with him
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:23 uses the metaphor of a signet ring to signify Zerubbabel’s special divine appointment and authority as God's chosen servant.

questions.question: Which historical king's reign is mentioned as the time reference for Haggai's prophecy in Haggai 2:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Darius
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:10 states that the prophecy was given in the second year of King Darius, placing the events in a specific Persian historical context.

questions.question: What type of literary device is used in Haggai 2:6-7 with the shaking of heavens, earth, sea, and dry land?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: The shaking of all elements is a metaphor in Haggai 2:6-7, symbolizing God's powerful, transformative intervention.

questions.question: True or False: Haggai 2:16-17 describes God’s judgment through natural disasters due to the people's disobedience.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:16-17 describes God smiting the people with blasting, mildew, and hail on their labors as a form of judgment because they did not turn to Him.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the promise in Haggai 2:9 about giving peace in the temple's place?
options: It foreshadows the Messianic peace and future restoration
It means the temple will never be troubled again
It refers to a political treaty with Persia
It implies cessation of all sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the Messianic peace and future restoration
questions.explanation: The promise of peace in Haggai 2:9 implies a future spiritual and eschatological peace associated with the temple, often linked to Messianic expectations.

questions.question: What does the question in Haggai 2:3 about seeing the house in its first glory highlight in terms of literary structure?
options: A contrast between past glory and present condition
A call for a new temple building style
questions.correctAnswer: A contrast between past glory and present condition
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:3 uses a rhetorical question to highlight a contrast between the temple's former glory and its current less impressive state, emphasizing the people's discouragement.

theological.title: Haggai Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Haggai Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: To whom does God command Haggai to speak in Haggai 2?
options: Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the residue of the people
questions.correctAnswer: Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the residue of the people
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:2 specifically commands speaking to Zerubbabel the governor, Joshua the high priest, and the rest of the people. This highlights God's leadership structure and covenant community. Similarly, God often addresses leaders and people together as in Exodus 3:10, Nehemiah 2:17, and Acts 7:38.

questions.question: What encouragement does God give Zerubbabel, Joshua, and the people in rebuilding the temple?
options: Be strong and work, for I am with you
questions.correctAnswer: Be strong and work, for I am with you
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:4 commands them to be strong and work because God is with them. This echoes God's promises of presence and strength seen in Joshua 1:9, Isaiah 41:10, Matthew 28:20, and Hebrews 13:5.

questions.question: What covenant does God remind them of regarding His Spirit remaining among them?
options: The covenant made when they came out of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: The covenant made when they came out of Egypt
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:5 references God's covenant at the Exodus, emphasizing continuity of God's Spirit and faithfulness. This covenant basis is foundational as seen in Exodus 19:5-6, Deuteronomy 7:9, Ezekiel 36:27, and Romans 11:2.

questions.question: What cosmic event does God declare He will perform 'yet once' in Haggai 2?
options: Shake the heavens, earth, sea, and dry land
Bring a flood to cleanse the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Shake the heavens, earth, sea, and dry land
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:6 states God will shake all creation, symbolizing divine judgment and renewal. This is consistent with Isaiah 13:13, Hebrews 12:26-27, Psalm 46:2-3, and Revelation 6:12-14 where God shakes creation as part of eschatological transformation.

questions.question: What will be filled with glory according to God's promise?
questions.correctAnswer: This house (the temple)
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:7 promises that God will fill the house (the temple) with glory, signifying His presence and blessing. This motif parallels Exodus 40:34-35, 1 Kings 8:10-11, Ezekiel 43:5, and John 1:14 where God's glory fills His dwelling place.

questions.question: Who owns the silver and gold according to Haggai 2?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:8 declares that silver and gold belong to the LORD of hosts, affirming God's sovereign ownership over all resources. This is echoed in Psalm 24:1, 1 Chronicles 29:11, Haggai 2:8, and James 1:17 emphasizing God's lordship over creation.

questions.question: How does the glory of the latter house compare to the former house?
options: The glory of the latter house will be greater
The former house had greater glory
The latter house will have no glory
questions.correctAnswer: The glory of the latter house will be greater
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:9 promises that the glory of the rebuilt temple will surpass the former. This foreshadows the greater glory of the Messianic age and New Covenant as in Isaiah 60:1-3, Ezekiel 43:1-5, John 2:19-21, and 2 Corinthians 3:7-18.

questions.question: What does God promise to give in the place of the temple?
questions.correctAnswer: Peace
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:9 ends with the promise 'in this place will I give peace.' The temple as God's dwelling is a place of shalom, consistent with Isaiah 9:6, John 14:27, Romans 5:1, and Philippians 4:7 where God grants peace to His people.

questions.question: According to Haggai 2, what happens if a person bearing holy flesh touches common food?
options: The food does not become holy
questions.correctAnswer: The food does not become holy
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:12 teaches that holy flesh touching bread or other food does not make the food holy, demonstrating distinctions in ritual purity. This aligns with Leviticus 22:4-7, Numbers 19:11-13, Hebrews 9:13, and Romans 14:14 clarifying holiness and contamination.

questions.question: What is the result if one unclean by touching a dead body touches food?
questions.correctAnswer: The food becomes unclean
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:13 states that if an unclean person touches food, the food becomes unclean, illustrating the transmission of uncleanness. This is consistent with Leviticus 11:24-28, Numbers 19:11-22, Ezekiel 22:26, and Mark 7:15 teaching about ritual purity.

questions.question: What does Haggai say about the people and their offerings in relation to uncleanness?
options: Their works and offerings are unclean before the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Their works and offerings are unclean before the LORD
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:14 declares the people and their works are unclean, indicating sin's defilement affecting worship. This aligns with Isaiah 64:6, Psalm 51:5, Romans 3:23, and Hebrews 10:22 emphasizing human sinfulness and need for cleansing.

questions.question: What agricultural problem do the people face that reflects their spiritual state?
questions.correctAnswer: Reduced harvest and yield
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:16 describes diminished harvests (20 measures yielding 10), symbolizing God's judgment and the people's unrepentance. This theme appears in Deuteronomy 28:38-40, Joel 1:10-12, Malachi 3:10, and James 5:7-8 linking obedience and blessing.

questions.question: What calamities does God say He sent upon the people's labors to get their attention?
questions.correctAnswer: Blasting, mildew, and hail
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:17 recounts God smiting the people with blasting, mildew, and hail to discipline them, but they did not turn to Him. Similar judgments occur in Exodus 9:23-25, Psalm 78:47, Amos 4:7, and Revelation 8:7 showing God's corrective hand.

questions.question: From what day does God promise to bless the people, despite current barrenness?
options: From the 24th day of the 9th month
From the first day of the 7th month
questions.correctAnswer: From the 24th day of the 9th month
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:18-19 commands the people to consider the 24th day of the 9th month, the day the temple foundation was laid, as the turning point for blessing. This emphasizes God's timing and covenant faithfulness as in Leviticus 23:24, Nehemiah 8:2, and 2 Corinthians 6:2.

questions.question: What future action will God perform concerning kingdoms and their strength?
options: Overthrow the throne of kingdoms and destroy their strength
questions.correctAnswer: Overthrow the throne of kingdoms and destroy their strength
questions.explanation: Haggai 2:22 predicts God will overthrow kingdoms and destroy their strength, indicating divine sovereignty and eschatological judgment. This is echoed in Daniel 2:44, Psalm 2:9, Revelation 19:19-21, and Isaiah 40:23-24 affirming God's control over nations.
